description: From Anglo-Norman surseser, from Old French sursis, past participle of surseoir, from Latin supersedere. Spelling later influenced by association with unrelated cease.

entries.meaning: Cessation; stop, stopping; end. Respite, intermission.
examples: And first of all, it is more then time, there were an ende and surcease made of this immodest and deformed manner of writting latelie entertained, whereby matter of religion is handled in the stile of the stage.

verbs.description: surcease (third-person singular simple present surceases, present participle surceasing, simple past and past participle surceased)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To come to an end; to desist.
examples: And instantly the storm surceases, the heavens clear, the sun comes forth in splendour, as a king entering the audience-hall, and sheds the glory of his presence over ship and sea and land.
The waves obedient to theyr beheast,
Them yielded ready passage, and their rage surceast.
